# 0. Preparation

------------------------------------------------------------------------

I need to install the following packages:



::: {.cell}


I was facing the error of installing devtools:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}

devtools::install_github("JohnCoene/charter")
```

# 3. The `{ggplot2}` Package

------------------------------------------------------------------------

A ggplot is built up from a few basic elements:

1.  **Data**;
2.  **Geometries** `geom_`: the geometric shape (h√¨nh h·ªçc) that will represent the data;
3.  **Aesthetics** `aes_`: aesthetics (t√≠nh th·∫©m m·ªπ) of the geometric or statistical objects, such as postition, color, size, shape, and transparency;
4.  **Scales** `scale_`: map between the data and the aesthetics dimensions (√°nh x·∫° t·ª´ d·ªØ li·ªáu ƒë·∫øn ƒë·ªì th·ªã), such as data range to plot width or factor values to colors;
5.  **Statistical transformations** `stat_`: statistical summaries (th·ªëng k√™) of data, such as quantitles, fitted curves, and sums;
6.  **Coordinate system** `coord_`: the transformation used for mapping data coordinates into the plane of the data rectangles (h·ªá t·ªça ƒë·ªô);
7.  **Facets** `facet_`: the arrangement of the data into a grid of plots;
8.  **Visual themes** `theme()`: the overall visual defaults of a plot, such as background, grids, axes, default typeface, sizes and colors (t√¥ng).

üöÄ **Kh√¥ng nh·∫•t thi·∫øt m·ªôt ph·∫ßn t·ª≠ ƒë∆∞·ª£c g·ªçi, v√† ch√∫ng c≈©ng c√≥ th·ªÉ ƒë∆∞·ª£c g·ªçi nhi·ªÅu l·∫ßn.**

# 4. A default `ggplot`

------------------------------------------------------------------------

Load the package for ability to use the functionality:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(ggplot2)
# library(tidyverse) # can also be imported from the tidy-universe!
```
:::



A default ggplot needs three things that you have to specify: the¬†*data*,¬†*aesthetics*, and a¬†*geometry.*

-   starting define a plot by using `ggplot(data = df)`;

-   if we want to plot (in most cases) 2 variables, we must add *positional aesthetics* `aes(x = var1, y = var2);`

üöÄ **Data ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë·ªÅ c·∫≠p *b√™n ngo√†i* `aes()`, trong khi ƒë√≥ bi·∫øn/variables ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë·ªÅ c·∫≠p *b√™n trong* `aes()`.**

V√≠ d·ª•:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
(g <- ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Just a blank panel, because `{ggplot2}` *does not know* how we plot data \~ we still need to provide geometry.

üöÄ **`ggplot2` cho ph√©p ch√∫ng ta l∆∞u `ggobject` th√†nh m·ªôt bi·∫øn, trong tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p n√†y l√† `g` . Ch√∫ng ta c√≥ th·ªÉ **m·ªü r·ªông** `g` b·∫±ng c√°ch th√™m c√°ch layers v·ªÅ sau.**

üöÄ **B·∫±ng c√°ch d√πng d·∫•u `()`, ch√∫ng ta c√≥ th·ªÉ *in* ngay object ƒë∆∞·ª£c g√°n ra.**

Many different geometries to use (called `geoms` because each function usually starts with `geom_`). For e.g., if we want to plot a scatter plot.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
g + geom_point()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



also a lineplot which our managers always like:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
g + geom_line()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



cool but the plot does not look optimal, we can also using mutiple layers of geometry, where the magic and fun start.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# it's the same if we write g + geom_line() + geom_point() 
g + geom_point() + geom_line()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



### Change properties of geometries

Turn all points to large fire-red diamonds:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
g + geom_point(color = 'firebrick', shape = 'diamond', size = 2)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



üöÄ **`ggplot2` hi·ªÉu khi ch√∫ng ta d√πng `color`, `colour`, c≈©ng nh∆∞ `col`.**

üöÄ **C√≥ th·ªÉ d√πng [m√†u m·∫∑c ƒë·ªãnh](http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~tzheng/files/Rcolor.pdf) ho·∫∑c [m√†u hex](https://www.techopedia.com/definition/29788/color-hex-code), ho·∫∑c th·∫≠m ch√≠ l√† m√†u RGB/RGBA v·ªõi h√†m `rgb()`. V√≠ d·ª•:**



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
g + geom_point(color = "#b22222", shape = "diamond", size = 2)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
g + geom_point(color = rgb(178, 34, 34, maxColorValue = 255), shape = "diamond", size = 2)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-2.png){width=672}
:::
:::



#### Replacing the default `ggplot2` theme

Calling eg `theme_bw()` using `theme_set()`, all following plots will have same blank'n'white theme.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
theme_set(theme_bw())

g + geom_point(color = 'firebrick')
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



üöÄ **`theme()` is also a useful function to modify all kinds of theme elements (texts, rectangles, and lines).**

# 5. Axes

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Change Axis Titles

Use `labs()` to assign character string for each lable.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
    geom_point(color = 'firebrick') +
    labs(x = 'Year', y = 'Temperature (¬∞F)')
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Can also using `xlab()` and `ylab()`:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
  geom_point(color = "firebrick") +
  xlab("Year") +
  ylab("Temperature (¬∞F)")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Not only the degree symbol before F, but also the supper script:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
  geom_point(color = "firebrick") +
  labs(x = "Year", y = expression(paste("Temperature (", degree ~ F, ")"^"(Hey, why should we use metric units?!)")))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



### Increase space between Axis and Axis Titles.

Overwrite the default `element_text()` within the `theme()` call:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
    geom_point(color = 'firebrick') +
    labs(x = 'Year', y = 'Temperature (¬∞F)') +
    theme(axis.title.x = element_text(vjust = 0, size = 30),
         axis.title.y = element_text(vjust = 2, size = 30))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



`vjust` refer to vertical alignment. We can also change the distance by specifying the margin of both text elements.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
  geom_point(color = "firebrick") +
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Temperature (¬∞F)") +
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(margin = margin(t = 10), size = 15),
        axis.title.y = element_text(margin = margin(r = 10), size = 15))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



`r` and `t` in the `margin` are **top** and **right**. Margin has 4 arguments: `margin(t, r, b, l)`. A good way to remember the order of the margin sides is ‚Äú***t-r***-ou-***b-l***-e‚Äù.

### Change Aesthetics of the Axis Titles

Again, we use `theme()` function and modify the `axis.tile` and/or the subordinated elements `axis.tile.x` and `axis.tile.y` . Within `element_text()` we can modify the default of `size`, `color`, and `face`.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
  geom_point(color = "firebrick") +
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Temperature (¬∞F)") +
  theme(axis.title = element_text(size = 15, color = "firebrick",
                                  face = "italic"))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



the `face` argument can be used to make the font `bold`, `italic`, or even `bold.italic`.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
  geom_point(color = "firebrick") +
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Temperature (¬∞F)") +
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(color = "sienna", size = 15, face = 'bold'),
        axis.title.y = element_text(color = "orangered", size = 15, face = 'bold.italic'))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-22-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



You could also use a combination of `axis.title` and `axis.title.y`, since `axis.title.x` inherits the values from `axis.title`. Eg:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
  geom_point(color = "firebrick") +
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Temperature (¬∞F)") +
  theme(axis.title = element_text(color = "sienna", size = 15),
        axis.title.y = element_text(color = "orangered", size = 15))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-23-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



One can modify some properties for both axis titles and other only for one or properties for each on its own:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
  geom_point(color = "firebrick") +
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Temperature (¬∞F)") +
  theme(axis.title = element_text(color = "sienna", size = 15, face = "bold"),
        axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold.italic"))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-24-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



### Change Aesthetics of Axis Text

Similar to the `title`, we can change the appearance of the axis text (number indeed) by using `axis.text` and/or the subordinated elements `axis.text.x` and `axis.text.y`.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
    geom_point(color = 'firebrick') +
    labs(x= "Year", y = expression(paste("Temperature(",degree ~ F, ")"))) +
    theme(axis.text = element_text(color = "dodgerblue", size = 13),
         axis.text.x = element_text(face = 'italic'))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-25-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



### Rotate Axis Text

Specifying an `angle` help us to rotate any text elements. With `hjust` and `vjust` we can adjust the position of text afterwards horizontally (0 = left, 1 = right), and vertically (0 = top, 1 = bottom).



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
    geom_point(color = 'firebrick') +
    labs(x= "Year", y = expression(paste("Temperature(",degree ~ F, ")"))) +
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 50, vjust = 1, hjust = 1, size = 13))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-26-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# 50 means 50 degrees, not % =)))
```
:::



### Remove Axis Text & Ticks

Rarely a reason to do this but this is how it works.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
  geom_point(color = "firebrick") +
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Temperature (¬∞F)") +
  theme(axis.ticks.y = element_blank(),
        axis.text.y = element_blank())
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



**üöÄIf you want to get rid of a theme element, the element is always `element_blank`.**

### Remove Axis Titles

We could again use `element_blank()` but it is way simpler to just remove the label in the `labs()` (or `xlab()`) call:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
  geom_point(color = "firebrick") +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-28-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Note that `NULL` removes the element (similarly to `element_blank()`) while empty quotes `""` will keep the spacing for the axis title and simply print nothing.

### Limit Axis Range

Some time you want to take a closer look at some range of you data. You can do this without subsetting your data:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
  geom_point(color = "firebrick") +
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Temperature (¬∞F)") +
  ylim(c(0, 50))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Warning: Removed 777 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_point()`).
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-29-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Alternatively you can use `scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 50))` (subset) or `coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, 50))`. The former removes all data points outside the range while the second adjusts the visible area (zooming) and is similar to `ylim(c(0, 50))` (subset).

### Force Plot to start at the origin



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
chic_high <- dplyr::filter(chic, temp > 25, o3 > 20)

ggplot(chic_high, aes(x = temp, y = o3)) +
  geom_point(color = "darkcyan") +
  labs(x = "Temperature higher than 25¬∞F",
       y = "Ozone higher than 20 ppb") +
  expand_limits(x = 0, y = 0)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-30-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Using `coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,NA), ylim = c(0,NA))` will lead to the same result.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
chic_high <- dplyr::filter(chic, temp > 25, o3 > 20)

ggplot(chic_high, aes(x = temp, y = o3)) +
  geom_point(color = "darkcyan") +
  labs(x = "Temperature higher than 25¬∞F",
       y = "Ozone higher than 20 ppb") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, NA), ylim = c(0, NA))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-31-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



But we can also force it to *literally* start at the origin!



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic_high, aes(x = temp, y = o3)) +
  geom_point(color = "darkcyan") +
  labs(x = "Temperature higher than 25¬∞F",
       y = "Ozone higher than 20 ppb") +
  expand_limits(x = 0, y = 0) +
  coord_cartesian(expand = FALSE, clip = "off")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-32-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



üöÄ **The argument `clip = "off"` in any coordinate system, always starting with `coord_*`, allows to draw outside of the panel area. Call it here to make sure that the tick marks at `c(0, 0)` are not cut.**

### Axes with Same Scaling

Use `coord_equal()` with default `ratio = 1` to ensure the units are equally scaled on the x-axis and on the y-axis. We can set the aspect ratio of a plot with `coord_fixed()` or `coord_equal()`. Both use `aspect = 1` (1:1) as a default.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = temp, y = temp + rnorm(nrow(chic), sd = 20))) +
  geom_point(color = "sienna") +
  labs(x = "Temperature (¬∞F)", y = "Temperature (¬∞F) + random noise") +
  xlim(c(0, 100)) + ylim(c(0, 150)) +
  coord_fixed()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Warning: Removed 47 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_point()`).
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-33-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Ratios higher than one make units on the y axis longer than units on the x-axis, and vice versa:



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = temp, y = temp + rnorm(nrow(chic), sd = 20))) +
  geom_point(color = "sienna") +
  labs(x = "Temperature (¬∞F)", y = "Temperature (¬∞F) + random noise") +
  xlim(c(0, 100)) + ylim(c(0, 150)) +
  coord_fixed(ratio = 1/5)
```

```
(`geom_point()`).
```

### Use a Function to Alter Labels

In case you want to format (eg adding % sign) without change the data.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
  geom_point(color = "firebrick") +
  labs(x = "Year", y = NULL) +
  scale_y_continuous(label = function(x) {return(paste(x, "Degrees Fahrenheit"))})
```

::: {.cell-output-display}

# 6. Titles

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Add a Title

We can add a title via `ggtitle()` function.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
    geom_point(color = "firebrick") +
    labs(x = "Year", y = "Temperature (¬∞F)") +
    ggtitle("Temperatures in Chicago")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-36-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Alternatively, we can use `labs()`, where we can add serveral arguments \~ metadata of the plot (a sub-title, a caption, and a tag):



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(chic, aes(x = date, y = temp)) +
    geom_point(color = "firebrick") +
    labs(x = "Year", y = "Temperature (¬∞F)",
        title = "Temperatures in Chicago",
        subtitle = "Seasonal pattern of daily temperatures from 1997 to 2001",
        caption = "Data: NMMAPS",
        tag = "Fig 1")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-37-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::
